In the case of 997, its reverse, 799, isn't prime, so 997 is just a prime number, not technically an emirp, though it often gets mentioned in discussions about primes due to its structure.

Certainly! The number 997 is indeed special for several reasons. It's a prime number, which means it has no divisors other than 1 and itself. As a four-digit number, it stands out because it's not only prime but also a part of a rare subset of prime numbers known as emirps. An emirp (prime spelled backwards) is a prime number that results in a different prime when its digits are reversed. In the case of 997, its reverse, 799, isn't prime, so 997 is just a prime number, not technically an emirp, though it often gets mentioned in discussions about primes due to its structure.

Moreover, 997 appears in various interesting mathematical contexts. For instance, when divided by 3, it gives a quotient that is almost exactly 332 with a very small remainder, which makes it an intriguing number in the context of divisibility and modular arithmetic.
